header: Bound by Their Closeness to Death
article:
Two men discuss Germany's coronavirus policies, one a biologist, the other a tiler. They hold contrasting opinions but find common ground nonetheless.
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
In the summer of 2017, ZEIT ONLINE
initiated a project called Germany Talks. Thousands of people signed up to meet
up with a neighbor who held contrasting political views for a face-to-face
debate. Since then, Germany Talks has taken place on a regular basis and more
than 60,000 people have taken part. On Sunday, May 10, thousands of people
around Germany met up once again to discuss the consequences of the coronavirus
pandemic – this time via video chat. Reports on the event can be read here.
Stefan Wehner would like to talk. Not
because he never gets the chance, but because he is hoping to meet someone who
doesn't see everything in black or white. Someone like his friend, who he used
to meet up with every Sunday for a conversation before the coronavirus arrived.
His friend always seemed to have his mind made up about everything.
"With him, it's either yes or
no," says Wehner, who has the feeling that he doesn't always get through
to his friend. He wants to know what it feels like to actually hold a
discussion with someone.
That's why he registered for Germany Talks.
The issue: the corona crisis. The call for participants noted: "Germany is
debating the correct course in the crisis. Talk about it with someone who has a
completely different approach than you do." Stefan Wehner, a 52-year-old
tiler, is hoping to find someone who doesn't listen just to retort, but who
listens to understand.
That someone is to be Burkhard Häfner, who has
a Ph.D. in biology. For the 55-year-old, the decision to take part was a
spontaneous one. He enjoys a good debate. Like all Germany Talks participants,
Häfner and Wehner were sent a questionnaire containing seven yes-or-no
questions.
Are the limits that have been placed on
public life commensurate? Wehner says yes, Häfner says no.
Should data privacy laws be loosened to
speed up the tracking of infection chains? Wehner says no, Häfner says yes.
Do you believe a nationwide requirement to
wear masks is correct? Wehner is opposed, Häfner in favor. 
They had opposite answers on all seven
questions.
But there is even more that divides them. Stefan
Wehner lives in a big city, Hamburg, while Burkhard Häfner lives in the
countryside between Würzburg and Frankfurt. Wehner is married with an 8-year-old
daughter while Häfner is single and has no children. Stefan Wehner has lived in
Germany his entire life; Häftner has spent many years abroad.
But there is one all-encompassing issue
that the two of them share: cancer. Häfner has survived his bout with the
illness and is now caring for his mother – who is suffering from it herself.
Wehner, meanwhile, will die of cancer, just as his grandmother and mother did
before him. Wehner takes a palliative approach to the disease, with no hope for
a cure.
"I'm not afraid of death," says
Wehner. Häfner, who frequently sprinkles English into his speech, says:
"There is no escaping it." The corona crisis is, essentially, a
matter of life and death. And that's a subject in which Häfner and Wehner are
experts.
A few days before their scheduled meeting,
the two of them exchange emails and agree to address each other using the
informal "du" form. They don't ask each other any questions in this
initial correspondence, nor do they write a word about corona. Instead, they talk
about themselves, inviting the other into their lives.
Then they talk over Skype. At first, the
camera doesn't work and the sound quality is poor. But after 10 minutes, it
starts working.
"So," says Stefan, "did the
German government react correctly to the corona crisis? You answered with
no."
Burkhard: "Essentially, I think they
reacted correctly, just much too late. That is the criticism I have. It's not
easy, of course, when you have only identified just a few infections. How can
you sell it to the electorate?"
Stefan: "I agree. Personally, I find
the measures appropriate, because you have to get the people behind you.
Otherwise, it leads to divisions in society."
Burkhard: "Yes, right."
At this point, the discussion is still well-balanced,
with the two of them exchanging arguments about how where they think the German
government could have done better and where not, where they ran up against the
limits of what is possible and in what aspects they maybe should have done
things differently.
"Hindsight, of course, is always
20-20," says Stefan. "But when I look back at everything, I arrive at
the conclusion that we reacted correctly."
Burkhard nods and suggests they move on.
"Question two," he says, " Are the limits that have been placed
on public life commensurate? I answered no, but what I meant was not really.
When you only have yes or no available as answers, it's hard to
differentiate."
Burkhard believes, for example, that the
needs of people in long-term care should have been considered to a much greater
degree. "Many people were forced to die alone – and not necessarily from
COVID-19 – because no family members were allowed to visit them." Particularly
for those suffering from dementia, he says, the current situation is especially
difficult.
Stefan: "No doubt about it. And I'm also
not so sure whether I could have found a better solution. But you simply have
to minimize the risk of carrying infections into care homes. Of course, human
tragedies are the result."
The limits on social contacts haven't
changed either of their lives to a great degree. Burkhard rarely leaves home
because he takes care of his mother. Stefan says: "At the moment, I hardly
go out at all. The last walk I took with my daughter was like an obstacle
course. There were simply too many people out on the streets."
As he speaks, Stefan reclines into a large
desk chair, and he will spend the rest of the discussion in exactly this
position. Burkhard also doesn't shift position, though he leans forward on a
table, as though he is trying to see and hear better, as though he wants to
keep moving forward. The feeling that he is somehow in a hurry will last
throughout the entire discussion, though he always lets his counterpart say his
piece. Only on those occasions when Stefan veers too far away from the issue at
hand does Burkhard guide him back to the list of questions. He'll says
something like: "What was the next question?" Still, they remain focused
on each other and they listen, asking questions like: "How do you see
it?"
Could such a thing have been expected? That
two people who had different responses to every single question would
nevertheless sit there nodding and smiling at each other?
Stefan increasingly takes over leadership
of the discussion. It seems as though he wants to get it all out, all of the
knowledge he has collected and prepared in his head. Perhaps he is also happy
that he has finally found someone who will sit there and listen.
The two agree that the government is facing
a challenge that isn't easy to solve. Stefan says that decisions for the entire
population must be made with the goal of protecting as many people as possible.
"But our society is much too diverse to always be able to consider every
individual aspect. You can't protect everybody. At the same time, I have
realized that measures that are useful and enforceable in one area are
completely impractical in others."
Burkhard: "That's true. You have to
stay flexible and can't constantly insist on the letter of the law."
Later, Burkhard will say: "Stefan's
perspective is more of society as a whole. It isn't so much one defined by the
individual and by the real worries he has, as it is with me."
From personal experience, Burkhard is fully
aware of the concerns that people can have at the moment, concerns that have
apparently been completely overlooked by the government. Perhaps that is why his
perspective is more focused on the individual. First, because of the pandemic, he
was no longer able to visit the people he was tending to as a hospice
volunteer. Not even their family members were allowed in. Then, when his mother
recently ended up in the hospital for a bone marrow biopsy, he wasn't able to
visit her either. "That was very difficult for her," he says. How can
you explain such a thing to someone that old? 
Stefan, though, says: "After I came
down with cancer, it was important to me to no longer think from the
perspective of an individual. I was over that. I know that I'm going to die no
matter what. I want to look at all of humanity."
Individual versus collective interests: Could
this contradiction contain the seeds of disagreement? No. The two of them don't
argue, not once. "When I view things from Stefan's perspective, I arrive
at similar conclusions," Burkhard says. Internalizing another person's perspective
is a skill. It's also something you have to want to do. And it's the only way
to gain understanding for another person. It's the only way to compare someone
else's ideas with your own, to challenge them and perhaps to correct them.
But perhaps the fact that they don't argue
can be explained by the fact that at second glance, they actually have quite a
bit in common. They both read the same kind of books – namely nonfiction focusing
on natural science or economics. They both spend a lot of time trying to
understand context, to learn and develop themselves further. And such a thing,
as they both know, is only possible when you listen.
But perhaps it also has to do with the fact
that both have gone through so much in life that they have no need for arguing.
Burkhard, the biologist, lost his father in
1991 to colon cancer. He then came down with cancer himself 10 years later as
he was working for a large pharmaceutical company in Belgium – on cancer
research. In a 10-hour operation, surgeons didn't just remove the tumor but
also half of his tongue. Thanks to plastic microsurgery, they were able to rebuild
his tongue, and after two years of speech therapy, he no longer had
difficulties talking. "Unless the weather changes," Burkhard says.
"Then, my scars harden and I have to choose words that I can still
pronounce well."
Then, his mother was diagnosed with breast
cancer. Burkhard quit his job and moved into his mother's house to take care of
her and is still doing so today. "It was my turn after my mother first sacrificed
herself to take care of my father and then took care of me for six months after
my cancer surgery." Burkhard's mother, who is 88, survived her bout with
cancer. But then, when the two of them were preparing a few weeks ago to
celebrate five years free of cancer, she was diagnosed on Friday, March 13,
with a bone marrow cancer. It was time to start all over again. More therapy,
more care. She now needs more help than ever, with everything. "What is it
they say? That fate can be a lousy traitor? But whatever. Other people have
other problems."
Other people like Stefan, the tiler. He too
has cancer, as did his mother and grandmother, both of whom died from the
disease. "My mother first came down with cancer in her mid-30s and then
was diagnosed with a new one every 10 years," he says. "No doctor
thought she would ever live to be 75."
Stefan's own cancer was found so late that
doctors could no longer figure out where it started. He was diagnosed with CUP
syndrome, which stands for "carcinoma with unknown primary tumor."
Stefan's body is full of metastases and an operation isn't an option. He
wouldn't be interested in one anyway, now that he has gone through myriad
treatments and the emotions and physical manifestations that have gone along
with them. Chemotherapy, for example: "You can't really describe what
happens to you. Sharp pains in your entire body, nausea, exhaustion.
Constantly. Basically, it feels like you're dying." Today, Stefan is no
longer fighting against cancer, he is living with it. For the last year, it
hasn't changed, getting neither worse nor better. "I'm content," he
says. "At the moment, I really am content."

Burkhard and Stefan know each other's story
from the emails they exchanged prior to their meeting. Because such experiences
often can't be described in words because of their intensity and complexity, it
helps to sit across from someone who has had a similar experience. It creates a
fundamental undercurrent of understanding and compassion. A certain serenity is
also the result, with neither of them believing they are irreplaceable. "You
shouldn't take yourself too seriously," Burkhard says. Stefan says:
"The world will keep turning, whether I'm there or not." The only
thing that Stefan really still cares about is giving his daughter the best
start in life that he can. "We should use all the possibilities available
to us to improve the future and our society," he says.
Neither Stefan nor Burkhard cling to life,
they embrace it. The most important thing to them is no longer money, prestige
or career success, but time. Time to read, time to think. They both know what a
privilege it is, particularly now at a time when each day brings more
information and studies about the dominant issue of corona, all of which must
be filtered, read, understood and pieced together to gain something approaching
comprehension.
Still, these two were chosen because of
their opposing viewpoints on a number of issues that they have come together to
discuss. And when it comes to the mask-wearing requirement, they aren't exactly
on the same page. Stefan is opposed to the requirement because most people
don't use them properly or they have a false sense of security when they wear
them and are no longer careful to keep sufficient distance from others.
Burkhard concedes the point, but sees masks as having more of a symbolic
importance, because they can reduce people's fears of leaving their home and
help them to feel more protected. At the same time, he says, masks are a
constant reminder of the dangers we are currently facing.
They are also at odds when it comes to online
schooling. Stefan believes that the steps that have thus far been taken
shouldn't be abandoned and that online activities motivate children to learn,
perhaps even more so and more effectively than lessons in the classroom.
Burkhard, though, says: "Children already spend too much time in front of
screens. If evolution had wanted that, it would have given us telepathic
abilities. Social competence is something that is best learned in interaction
with others, in face-to-face communication." They agree that a combination
of the two would be the right strategy.
They continue talking – about the stock
market, about the force of nature represented by this virus that cares nothing
about our economy, about technological developments and the future of humanity,
about the level of immunity in the population, about the importance of nuanced
approaches, about the looming division of society. Neither of the two is
seeking to score points in the discussion. They really are only interested in exchanging
views and finding out where the other's priorities lie – and what views result
from that.
Perhaps it isn't necessary to constantly
argue. Perhaps the goal of such a discussion should simply be that of allowing
the space necessary to the complexities of life and to process them – or at
least to withstand them. 
Almost two hours have passed by the time
Burkhard suddenly is no longer looking into the camera, but past it. He is no
longer really listening. It is the only time that he interrupts Stefan in the
middle of the sentence. "Hey, I think I have to stop. You know why. My
mother needs me. It was an interesting and wide-ranging discussion that I would
be happy to continue at some point."
"No worries," Stefan responds
with a smile.
"Be well."
"All the best."
